questions.text: A 69-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department with an acute UGI hemorrhage following a bout of repeated vomiting. Fiberoptic gastroscopy reveals three linear mucosal tears at the GE junction. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mallory-Weiss tear Mallory -Weiss tear is characterized by acute and sometimes massive UGI hemorrhage . It accounts for up to 10% of UGI bleeds. It is due to arterial bleeding following repeated vomiting (which causes mucosal tears at the GE junction). The cause is the same as that for spontaneous rupture of the esophagus (i.e., an increase in intra-abdominal pressure against a closed glottis). Causes other than vomiting such as paroxysmal coughing or retching, may sometimes lead to this condition. Upper endoscopy confirms the diagnosis.

Highyeild:

Mallory - Weiss tear Mallory-Weiss tears are partial-thickness tears of the mucosa and submucosa near the gastroesophageal junction. These tears are caused by forceful contraction of the abdominal wall against an unrelaxed cardio, resulting in increased intragastric pressure and mucosal laceration. They were originally associated with alcoholic patients who had a history of intense retching and vomiting following binge drinking, but they can occur in any patient who has a history of repeated vomiting. Mallory-Weiss tears account for 5% to 10% of cases of upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB). Diagnosis is usually made by history, and endoscopy is used to confirm the diagnosis. A retroflection maneuver is necessary to view the area just below the gastroesophageal junction to avoid missing this diagnosis in UGIB patients. Most tears occur along the lesser curvature and can extend into the esophagus. Supportive therapy with acid suppression therapy is successful in 90% of bleeding episodes, with the mucosa often healing within 72 hours. In rare cases of severe ongoing bleeding, endoscopic therapy with injection or electrocoagulation may be effective. If these therapies fail, angioembolization with absorbable material such as a gelatin sponge has been successfully employed.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Reflux esophagitis is esophageal inflammation secondary to repeated exposure of the esophageal mucosa to the acidic gastric secretions in gastroesophageal reflux disease leads to an inflammatory response that can result in chronic blood loss. Ulceration may accompany this, but the superficial mucosal ulcerations generally do not bleed acutely and are more commonly manifested as anemia or guaiac-positive stools . Option: B. Barrett’s esophagus is a metaplastic change in the lining mucosa of the esophagus in response to chronic gastro-oesophageal Reflux. The hallmark of ‘specialized’ Barrett’s epithelium is the presence of mucus-secreting goblet cells (intestinal metaplasia) Option: C. Squamous cell carcinoma generally affects the upper two-thirds of the esophagus and adenocarcinoma the lower third. They present usually with ulcers with everted or irregular edges than linear ulcers

Extraedge:

In cases of failed endoscopic therapy, it is important to rule out variceal bleeding by thoroughly examining the gastroesophageal junction. Recurrent bleeding from a Mallory-Weiss tear is uncommon.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman with Sjörgen’s syndrome complains of fatigue and melena. She is pale and anemic. Endoscopy reveals ectatic vessels radiating from the pylorus. Which of the following diagnosis is true?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Watermelon Stomach “Watermelon stomach” is a term used to describe the appearance of the stomach in a condition called GAVE (gastric antral vascular ectasis) syndrome. Dilated blood vessels radiate from the pylorus to the antrum in a pattern that resembles the stripes of a watermelon. It is an uncommon cause of gastrointestinal bleeding. It has been associated with certain autoimmune diseases, however, it may also be seen in individuals not affected by these conditions. It may also be seen with portal hypertension. APC is used for its management.

Highyeild:

Gastric Amtrak vascular ectasia Endoscopic image of en: gastric antral vascular ectasia seen as a radial pattern around the pylorus before (top) and after (bottom) treatment with argon plasma coagulation Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE ) is named after the parallel red stripes found on the mucosal folds of the distal stomach. Histologically, GAVE is characterized by enlarged blood vessels containing thrombi in the lamina propria, as well as mucosal fibromuscular hyperplasia and hyalinization. GAVE is similar in appearance to portal hypertensive gastropathy, but GAVE is typically found in the distal stomach while portal hypertensive gastropathy usually affects the proximal stomach. Beta-blockers and nitrates are not effective in treating GAVE, which is typically found in elderly women with chronic gastrointestinal blood loss requiring transfusion. GAVE may be associated with an autoimmune connective tissue disorder , and at least a quarter of patients have chronic liver disease .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Mallory-Weiss tear is characterized by acute and sometimes massive UGI hemorrhage. It is due to arterial bleeding following repeated vomiting (which causes mucosal tears at the GE junction). Option: C. Schatzki’s ring is circular in the distal esophagus usually at the squamocolumnar junction . The core of the ring consists of variable amounts of fibrous tissue and cellular infiltrate. Most rings are incidental findings. Option: D. In portal HTN , portal blood flow is diverted away from the higher-pressure portal system through the paraumbilical veins to the lower-pressure veins of the anterior abdominal wall. In this setting, dilated superficial paraumbilical veins are termed caput medusae .

Extraedge:

Treatment options for GAVE include estrogen and progesterone , as well as endoscopic treatment with the neodymium yttrium-aluminum-garnet (Nd: YAG) laser or argon plasma coagulator . If these options are ineffective, an antrectomy may be necessary to control blood loss. However, this operation is riskier for elderly patients. For patients with both portal hypertension and antral vascular ectasia , a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt ( TIPSS ) may be considered.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with a massive UGI bleed. After resuscitation, an endoscopy is performed. No esophageal varices, gastritis, or gastric ulcers are seen. After copious irrigation, a pinpoint lesion is seen near the GE junction. What can be said about this lesion?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a Mallory – Weiss tear

options.label: D
options.text: Bleeding is from a submucosal vessel.

questions.correct_answer: D. Bleeding is from a submucosal vessel.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bleeding is from a submucosal vessel. A dieulafoy lesion is an uncommon cause of UGI bleeding (0.3–7%). It can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract but is most commonly found in the stomach (near the GE junction). It is often difficult to visualize because of its small size. A dilated submucosal artery is the source of the bleeding. First-line management is therapeutic endoscopy. There is no association with NSAIDs or alcohol.

Highyeild:

A Dieulafoy lesion is a malformation found in the gastric arterial-venous system with a unique histological appearance. It can cause severe upper gastrointestinal bleeding that is difficult to manage. The lesion is usually covered by normal mucosa and may not be visible when not bleeding. Profuse bleeding from an area of normal mucosa indicates the cause of bleeding is the Dieulafoy lesion . Endoscopic identification of the lesion can be done, and bleeding can be stopped by sclerosant injection or endoscopic clip application. Local excision is the only necessary treatment if the lesion is identified during surgery.

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Mallory -Weiss tear is characterized by acute and sometimes massive UGI hemorrhage. It is due to arterial bleeding following repeated vomiting (which causes mucosal tears at the GE junction). Option: B.Barrett’s esophagus is a metaplastic change in the lining mucosa of the esophagus in response to chronic gastro-oesophageal Reflux. The hallmark of ‘specialized’ Barrett’s epithelium is the presence of mucus-secreting goblet cells (intestinal metaplasia) Option: C. Squamous cell carcinoma generally affects the upper two-thirds of the esophagus and adenocarcinoma the lower third. They present usually with ulcers with everted or irregular edges than linear ulcers

Extraedge:

Dieulafoy lesions are relatively rare , accounting for only 1-2% of cases of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. The exact cause of Dieulafoy lesions is unknown , but they are thought to be congenital or acquired. Patients with a Dieulafoy lesion may experience symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and dizziness in addition to bleeding. Endoscopic ultrasound can be used to detect Dieulafoy lesions that may be missed during standard endoscopy. Dieulafoy lesions can occur in other areas of the body, including the colon and the bronchus .

questions.text: A 63-year-old male presents with rapidly progressive dysphagia and profound weight loss. He is pale and cachectic. He does not complain of hematemesis but there is a history of Malena. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Duodenal ulcer PUD is responsible for up to two-thirds of UGIBs and can develop in the stomach or duodenum. Approximately 10% to 15% of patients with PUD will develop bleeding as part of their disease course. Significant bleeding does not occur until the erosion reaches an artery of the submucosa or an even larger vessel in the case of a penetrating ulcer.

Highyeild:

Demographic changes have occurred in patients with duodenal ulceration in the West. The use of gastric antisecretory agents and pylori eradication therap y for dyspepsia has contributed to these changes. The peak incidence of duodenal ulceration is now in an older age group, and the gender difference is less marked. These changes reflect the changes in the epidemiology of pylori infection. Duodenal ulcers are most commonly found in the first part of the duodenum. Chronic ulcers can lead to fibrosis and deformities such as pyloric stenosis . Healing may leave a residual scar in the mucosa. Multiple ulcers may be present, known as "kissing ulcers."

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Squamous cell carcinoma generally affects the upper two-thirds of the esophagus and adenocarcinoma the lower third. They present usually with ulcers with everted or irregular edges than linear ulcers Option: B. GERD presents with a history of heartburn and reflux. However, the history of Malena is rare. The patient has difficulty in eating but is rarely pale and cachectic Option: D. Achalasia (Greek ‘failure to relax’) is due to the loss of the ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach’s) plexus, the cause of which is unknown. The classic physiological abnormalities are a non-relaxing LOS and absent peristalsis in the body of the esophagus.

Extraedge:

Anterior ulcers tend to perforate , while posterior ulcers tend to bleed. The entire duodenal cap may be ulcerated and devoid of mucosa in rare cases. Giant duodenal ulcers are usually benign. Microscopically, the base of the ulcer is covered with granulation tissue . Pathological interpretations of healing ulcers must be careful, as epithelial down growth can be misinterpreted as an invasion.

questions.text: A 78-year-old female presents with upper GI bleed and melaena. She has been on long-term NSAIDs for her arthritis.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gastritis Erosive gastritis is caused by agents that disturb the gastric mucosal barrier; NSAIDs and alcohol are common causes. The NSAID-induced gastric lesion is associated with the inhibition of the cyclo-oxygenase type 1 (COX-1) receptor enzyme, hence reducing the production of cytoprotective prostaglandins in the stomach. Many of the beneficial anti-inflammatory activities of NSAIDs are mediated by COX-2, and the use of specific COX-2 inhibitors reduces the incidence of these side effects. However, taken in long-term COX-2 inhibitors are associated with cardiovascular complications in common with many NSAIDs.

Highyeild:

Stress gastritis is characterized by multiple superficial erosions that start in the proximal or acid-secreting part of the stomach and progress distally, almost always seen in the fundus and rarely in the diastal stomach. Impaired mucosal defense mechanisms against luminal acids, such as a reduction in blood flow, mucus, and bicarbonate secretion by mucosal cells, or a reduction in endogenous prostaglandins, is a key factor in the pathophysiology of stress gastritis. Risk factors or predisposing clinical conditions for stress gastritis include ARDS, multiple trauma, major burns, hepatic dysfunction, oliguric renal failure, large transfusion requirements, hypotension, prolonged surgical procedures, and sepsis. More than 50% of patients develop stress gastritis within 1-2 days after a traumatic event, and the only clinical sign may be painless upper GI bleeding that may be delayed at the onset. Treatment for stress gastritis involves definitive fluid resuscitation with correction of any coagulation abnormalities and treatment of the underlying sepsis. Intraluminal gastric pH should be maintained above 5.0 with antisecretory agents. Prophylaxis measures for stress gastritis include complete neutralization of luminal acid or antisecretory therapy, sepsis control, ventilatory support, adequate nutrition, and correction of dyselectrolytemia. Gastric volvulus is a condition where the stomach rotates on its axis, and it can be of two types: organoaxial and mesenteroaxial .

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Squamous cell carcinoma generally affects the upper two-thirds of the esophagus and adenocarcinoma the lower third. They present usually with ulcers with everted or irregular edges than linear ulcers Option: B. GERD presents with a history of heartburn and reflux. However, the history of Malena is rare. The patient has difficulty in eating but is rarely pale and cachectic Option: C. PUD is responsible for up to two-thirds of UGIBs and can develop in the stomach or duodenum. Approximately 10% to 15% of patients with PUD will develop bleeding as part of their disease course. Significant bleeding does not occur until the erosion reaches an artery of the submucosa or an even larger vessel in the case of a penetrating ulcer.

Extraedge:

Primary gastric volvulus is seen in association with congenital asplenia and wandering spleen, while secondary gastric volvulus occurs secondary to some anatomic abnormality, most commonly diaphragmatic hernia. The major symptoms at presentation of gastric volvulus are acute-onset abdominal pain, distention, vomiting, and upper GI hemorrhage. Borchardt's triad (epigastric pain, inability to vomit, and inability to pass a nasogastric tube) is highly suggestive of gastric volvulus.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents with sudden onset upper GI bleeding. He is resuscitated and posted for an upper GI endoscopy which shows a Dieulafoy lesion. All are true about this lesion EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Angiographic embolization is the preferred treatment

options.label: C
options.text: Pulsation of the artery causes ulceration

questions.correct_answer: A. Angiographic embolization is the preferred treatment
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Angiographic embolization is the preferred treatment Dieulafoy lesions are vascular malformations found primarily along the lesser curve of the stomach within 6 cm of the gastroesophageal junction, although they can occur elsewhere in the GI tract Erosion of the gastric mucosa overlying these sizable vessels (1 to 3 mm) found in the gastric submucosa leads to bleeding. The mucosal defect is usually small (2 to 5 mm), without an associated ulcer, thus making it difficult to identify. Given the large size of the underlying artery, bleeding from a Dieulafoy lesion can be massive. Initial attempts at endoscopic control are often successful. The application of thermal or sclerosant therapy is effective in 80% to 100% of cases. In cases that fail endoscopic therapy, angiographic coil embolization can also be successful. If these approaches are unsuccessful, surgical intervention may be necessary; because of difficulties in visualization and palpation of these lesions, prior endoscopic tattooing or clipping can facilitate the procedure. A gastrotomy is performed, and attempts are made at identifying the bleeding source. The lesion can then be oversewn.

It can cause severe upper gastrointestinal bleeding that is difficult to manage. The lesion is usually covered by normal mucosa and may not be visible when not bleeding. Profuse bleeding from an area of normal mucosa indicates the cause of bleeding is the Dieulafoy lesion. Endoscopic identification of the lesion can be done, and bleeding can be stopped by sclerosant injection or endoscopic clip application. Local excision is the only necessary treatment if the lesion is identified during surgery.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with a massive UGI bleed. He was resuscitated in the Casualty and then posted for an emergency endoscopy. During the endoscopy, it was observed that according to Forrest Classification, there was a high risk of rebleeding. Which of the following is NOT associated with a high risk of bleeding in the Forrest Classification?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adherent clot

Highyeild:

The Forrest classification is used to assess the risk of re-bleeding based on endoscopic findings in patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB). The classification groups patients into the high, intermediate, and low risk of re-bleeding . Endoscopic therapy is recommended for ulcers with active bleeding or a visible ulcer (Forrest I-IIa), while ulcers with a clean base or black spot secondary to hematoma deposition (Forrest IIc-III) do not require endoscopic treatment and are managed medically. If endoscopic intervention is needed, approximately 25% of patients undergoing EGD for UGIB will require it. If endoscopic therapy is unsuccessful, angiography is recommended, and surgery is the next step if angiography fails or is not available. All patients with confirmed peptic ulcer bleed should receive PPI therapy. Preendoscopic high-dose IV PPI therapy is associated with a decreased frequency of high-risk findings on endoscopy (Forrest Ia-IIa) and reduces the need for endoscopic intervention. Continuing PPI therapy post-endoscopy also reduces the risk of further bleeding, the need for surgery, and mortality. Eradication of H. pylori infection, if present, results in less re-bleeding, and confirmation of successful therapy should be done

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a massive UGI bleed. He was resuscitated in the Casualty and then posted for an emergency endoscopy. In the case of UGI bleeding, all are true about endoscopy Except:

options.label: B
options.text: Leads to early discharge of patient

options.label: C
options.text: Can detect causes in all cases

options.label: D
options.text: Best tool for localization of bleeding

questions.correct_answer: C. Can detect causes in all cases
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Can detect causes in all cases Endoscopy may not be able to detect the cause of bleeding in all cases especially if it's in a condition like Dieulafoy’s lesion. Therapeutic endoscopy can achieve hemostasis in approximately 70% of cases, with the best evidence supporting a combination of adrenaline injection with a heater probe and/or clips. Therapeutic endoscopy will probably never be effective in patients who are bleeding from large vessels and with which the majority of the mortality is associated. In patients where the source of bleeding cannot be identified or in those who rebleed after endoscopy, angiography with transcatheter embolization may offer a valuable alternative to surgery in expert centers.

Highyeild:

Medical treatment for bleeding is often limited in effectiveness. Initial treatment typically involves administering an H2 antagonist or a proton pump inhibitor. Recent evidence supports the use of proton pump inhibitors after endoscopy to prevent rebleeding. Tranexamic acid, an inhibitor of fibrinolysis, may reduce overall mortality. Therapeutic endoscopy can achieve hemostasis in about 70% of cases. The most effective treatment involves a combination of adrenaline injection with a heater probe and/or clips. Therapeutic endoscopy may not be effective in patients who are bleeding from large vessels, which is associated with the majority of mortality.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A, B, & D. are true statements.

Extraedge:

Angiography with transcatheter embolization may be a valuable alternative to surgery in cases where the source of bleeding cannot be identified or if the patient rebleeds after endoscopy. The risk of significant ischemia following embolization is low due to the rich collateral blood supply of the stomach and duodenum. Rescue surgery after failed embolization is associated with poor outcomes, and it may be advantageous to proceed directly to surgery. If bleeding continues, surgical intervention is required except in centers with experience in angiographic embolization, where attempts may be made to arrest bleeding and avoid surgery.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department with an acute UGI hemorrhage. He is a known smoker and known to consume over-the-counter pain medications for joint pain. He is resuscitated in the Emergency department. The investigation of choice now would be?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endoscopy Therapeutic endoscopy can achieve hemostasis in approximately 70% of cases, with the best evidence supporting a combination of adrenaline injection with a heater probe and/or clips. Therapeutic endoscopy will probably never be effective in patients who are bleeding from large vessels and with which the majority of the mortality is associated.

Highyeild:

Acute upper gastrointestinal (UGI) hemorrhage is a medical emergency, and endoscopy is the most effective method to identify the bleeding source and stop the bleeding. Endoscopy can also provide information on the severity of the bleeding and help guide further management decisions. Angiography and CT scans may be used in certain situations, such as if endoscopy is inconclusive or if the patient is unstable and cannot undergo endoscopy. Barium studies are not recommended in acute UGI bleeding due to the risk of aspiration and lack of sensitivity in detecting active bleeding.

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. In patients where the source of bleeding cannot be identified or in those who rebleed after endoscopy, angiography with transcatheter embolization may offer a valuable alternative to surgery in expert centers. Option: C .Multiphase CT enterography can be superior to capsule endoscopy in detecting bleeding from tumors. Typically, it is performed with a neutral or low-density oral contrast to distend the small bowel and includes IV contrast. Scans are performed in the arterial, enteral, and delayed phases. If a patient is stable and can tolerate capsule endoscopy and CT enterography, these studies are complementary Option: D . Barium studies are of no use in the emergency setting of an upper GI bleed because it is time-consuming as well as vomiting which may not permit a barium study in the first place.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department with an acute UGI hemorrhage. He is a known smoker and known to consume over-the-counter pain medications for joint pain. He is resuscitated in the Emergency department. He underwent an upper GI endoscopy which was not able to detect the site of bleeding and was posted for an angiography. Which of the following statements is the INCORRECT statement regarding?

options.label: A
options.text: The sensitivity of angiography for detecting GI bleeding is about 10-20% as compared to nuclear imaging

options.label: B
options.text: Angiography can image bleeding at a rate of 0.05 – 0.1 ml/ min or less

options.label: C
options.text: Angiography can be used in case of a failed endoscopy

options.label: D
options.text: Vasopressin infusion can be used to reduce bleeding.

questions.correct_answer: B. Angiography can image bleeding at a rate of 0.05 – 0.1 ml/ min or less
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Angiography can image bleeding at a rate of 0.05 – 0.1 ml/ min or less Angiography is diagnostic as well as therapeutic and should be considered if a patient has failed endoscopic management or if the bleeding has not been localized. Access is obtained through the common femoral artery. The superior mesenteric artery and inferior mesenteric artery can also be evaluated if no bleeding is identified. Success rates for UGIB embolization are cited at 44% to 100% and 88% to 93% for LGIB. Vasopressin infusion is less frequently used now that improved methods of transcatheter embolization are available. The mechanism of action is that vasopressin constricts arteries to reduce blood flow to the site of hemorrhage.

Highyeild:

Angiography is both diagnostic and therapeutic for cases where endoscopic management has failed or bleeding cannot be localized. Access is obtained through the common femoral artery , and the vessel to be interrogated first is based on clinical suspicion of the location of the bleed. For suspected UGIB, the celiac artery and its branches are typically evaluated first, while the superior and inferior mesenteric arteries may also be evaluated if no bleeding is identified. Provocative maneuvers with systemic anticoagulation may be considered for patients with repetitive, nondiagnostic workups, but the risk of uncontrolled hemorrhage must be weighed against the potential benefits. Transcatheter arterial embolization is effective for controlling bleeding when a source is found, with super-selective embolization allowing for adequate collateral flow to prevent bowel infarction. Embolic agents like coils, polyvinyl alcohol particles, Gelfoam, glue, and plugs may be used, with coils and polyvinyl alcohol particles being the most commonly used. Success rates for UGIB embolization are cited at 44% to 100%, while success rates for LGIB are 88% to 93%.

Extraedge:

Vasopressin infusion is less frequently used now due to the high rates of rebleeding after cessation of infusion and the need to maintain vascular access in situ for 24 to 48 hours to continue the infusion. Vasopressin may be useful if there is diffuse bleeding or as a bridge to surgical intervention if super-selective cannulation cannot be achieved.

questions.text: A 50-year-old company executive presents in the casualty with hypotension and hematemesis. There is previous history suggestive of alcohol intake of 200 ml daily. The blood loss is around 2 liters. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Duodenal ulcer PUD is responsible for up to two-thirds of UGIBs and can develop in the stomach or duodenum. Approximately 10% to 15% of patients with PUD will develop bleeding as part of their disease course. PUD results from an imbalance between mucosal barriers and other aggravating factors. The major etiologic factors in PUD are H. pylori and NSAIDs, and in some patients, these can act synergistically in the development of ulcers through their additive insults to the gastroduodenal mucosa. NSAIDs also disrupt the mucosal barrier but via a different mechanism. NSAIDs inhibit cyclooxygenases (i.e., COX-1 and COX-2), thus impairing prostaglandin synthesis, enhancing neutrophil adherence, and subsequent mucosal injury. The most significant hemorrhage occurs when duodenal or gastric ulcers penetrate branches of the gastroduodenal or left gastric arteries, respectively.

Highyeild:

Demographic changes have occurred in patients with duodenal ulceration in the West. The use of gastric antisecretory agents and pylori eradication therap y for dyspepsia has contributed to these changes. The peak incidence of duodenal ulceration is now in an older age group, and the gender difference is less marked. These changes reflect the changes in the epidemiology of pylori infection. Duodenal ulcers are most commonly found in the first part of the duodenum. Chronic ulcers can lead to fibrosis and deformities such as pyloric stenosis . Healing may leave a residual scar in the mucosa. Multiple ulcers may be present, known as "kissing ulcers."

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A, C & D. Gastritis, Mallory Weiss tear, and esophageal varices are all causes of upper GI bleed but are less common when compared to bleeding secondary to duodenal ulcer.

Anterior ulcers tend to perforate , while posterior ulcers tend to bleed. The entire duodenal cap may be ulcerated and devoid of mucosa in rare cases. Giant duodenal ulcers are usually benign. Microscopically, the base of the ulcer is covered with granulation tissue . Pathological interpretations of healing ulcers must be careful, as epithelial down growth can be misinterpreted as an invasion.

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency ward with a massive upper GI bleed. On examination, he has mild splenomegaly. In the absence of any other information available, which of the following is the most appropriate therapeutic modality?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intravenous pantoprazole All patients with confirmed peptic ulcer bleed should receive PPI therapy . Preendoscopic high-dose IV PPI therapy has been associated with decreased frequency of high-risk findings on endoscopy ( Forrest Ia–IIa ), leading to less need for endoscopic intervention. This approach has been shown to reduce the risk of further bleeding, the need for surgery, and mortality.

Highyeild:

Pantoprazole is a proton pump inhibitor that reduces the production of gastric acid, which can help control active bleeding in the upper gastrointestinal tract. Intravenous propranolol and intravenous vasopressin are not appropriate treatments for upper GI bleeding. Intravenous somatostatin is an alternative treatment option for upper GI bleeding, but it is less commonly used than PPIs. Mild splenomegaly is not sufficient to guide the choice of treatment, and further evaluation is needed to identify the cause of the bleeding and appropriate management.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A, B & D. Vasopressin , propranolol, and somatostatin are all drugs of choice once the cause for the bleeding is established following upper GI endoscopy. However, in the presence of any other information not being available, an upper GI bleed is considered to be due to peptic ulcer disease, and hence pantoprazole IV or oral is started.

Endoscopic therapies are used to treat PUD, including injection, thermal coagulation, plasma argon coagulation, mechanical clips, and fibrin glue.
